questions.text: An 11-year old boy presented with pain and swelling around his knee. His radiograph is as shown below. Biopsy revealed blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is an aneurysmal bone cyst.

The above clinical scenario of an 11-year old boy with pain and swelling and radiograph findings showing lytic lesion of the metaphysis of the upper tibia and biopsy showing blood-filled cystic spaces leads to the diagnosis of an aneurysmal bone cyst.

An aneurysmal bone cyst is a benign, expansile lytic lesion of the metaphysis of the long bones that are comprised of blood-filled cystic spaces. It is more common between the age group of 5-20 years with equal male: female distribution. They occur more commonly in the metaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, and humerus. It may occur on the posterior elements of the spine.

Patients usually present with pain and swelling. In cases of spinal involvement, neurologic manifestations can be seen due to nerve root impingement and neurological impairment.

Diagnosis:

A plain radiograph shows an expansile, lytic lesion in the metaphysis. MRI reveals a typical cystic lesion and numerous intralesional septations along with fluid-fluid levels. A biopsy would reveal blood-filled cystic spaces with fibrous septations which might consist of woven bone.

Treatment:

Curettage and bone grafting are done in most cases. Arterial embolization is preferred in cases where curettage is extremely difficult. Low-dose radiation is also effective but avoided in view of potential malignant transformation.

Other options:

Option B- Osteoclastoma (giant cell tumor) is a benign but locally aggressive tumor. It usually affects young adults with a peak incidence in the age group of 20-45 years. A plain radiograph reveals an eccentric, expansile, lobulated lytic lesion in the epiphysis. There is minimal calcification within the tumor. Biopsy reveals osteoclast-like giant cells scattered among round or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. 

Below is the image showing osteoclastoma:

 

Option C- Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors that present commonly in the adolescent age group. Radiograph and MRI would reveal pedunculated bony protuberance with a stalk (as shown below) or some lesions with a broad sessile base. Histology shows the cap composed of benign hyaline cartilage covered with a perichondrium, disorganised growth plate and endochondral ossification in the stalk and inner portion of the head. 

 

Option D- Simple bone cyst is a unilocular cystic bone cavity that is filled with serous or serosanguinous fluid. It presents most commonly in the first two decades of life. The most common site is proximal humeral metaphysis most commonly affecting metaphysis close to the physis. On the radiograph, a centrally located, lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline is seen. Histology shows connective tissue lining with foci of reactive bone.

When a fracture occurs, a fragment is seen in the cavity referred to as the fallen fragment sign as shown below:

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with frequently changing bowel habits. He noticed blood in the stools which were not associated with pain. There was no history of weight loss. Barium enema was done and the image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is colonic diverticulosis.

The above clinical scenario with the barium enema image is suggestive of colonic diverticulosis. The barium enema given shows multiple outpouchings in the ascending, transverse, and descending colon resembling a saw-tooth.  

Diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. Colonic diverticulosis is more common among the age group of more than 50 years. Colonic diverticulosis is primarily false diverticula as only the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated. Due to the high intraluminal pressure, they are referred to as the pulsion type of diverticula. A low fibre diet results in smaller stool volume that increases intraluminal pressure for propulsion. The higher pressures get directed to the colonic wall resulting in pulsion diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common location.

The majority of the patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with abdominal cramps, altered bowel habits, and painless rectal bleeding. Diverticulosis can present with complications like:

  • Diverticulitis
  • Abscess
  • Peritonitis
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Hemorrhage 
  • Fistula formation

Diagnosis:

The diagnosis is confirmed by a colonoscopy or an X-ray barium enema. Barium enema radiograph shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth. In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

Treatment:

A high fibre diet reduces the incidence of diverticulosis. Antispasmodics can be prescribed to reduce intestinal spasms. Most cases of bleeding are self-limiting. If persistent bleeding is present, surgical, endoscopic or radiological interventions can be done to reduce the bleeding.

Other options:

Option B- Carcinoma colon shows apple-core sign on barium enema as shown below. 

 

Option C- Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows the string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below.

 

Option D- Intussusception shows the coiled-spring appearance on barium enema as shown below.

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text: Identify the amputation done at the level shown in the below radiograph.
questions.solution:
Chopart amputation is done at the level shown in the above radiograph.

Chopart amputation is a type of midfoot amputation through the talonavicular joint and calcaneocuboid joint. One of the indications is diabetic foot. It can be done only if calcaneum and talus are free of infection.

The image below shows X-ray foot after Chopart's amputation.

Other options:

Option A: Pirogoff amputation is a type of hindfoot amputation. It involves a vertical section through the middle of the calcaneum followed by arthrodesis between the tibia and the remaining part of the calcaneum.

Option B: Syme's amputation is a type of hindfoot amputation where the bone section is done at the distal tibia and fibula.

Option C: Lisfranc amputation is a type of midfoot amputation that is done at the level of tarsometatarsal joints.

questions.text: A cervical radiograph of a patient involved in a road traffic accident is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hangman's fracture.

The given cervical radiograph shows fracture of the pedicles of the C2 vertebra with an anterior translation of C2 over the C3 vertebra thus giving the diagnosis of hangman's fracture.

The mechanism of a traumatic hangman's fracture is hyperextension due to force to the forehead along with axial loading. It was incorrectly referred to previously as hangman's fracture due to the distractive force and death from spinal cord injury in judicial hanging. This results in anterior translation of the C2 vertebra over the C3 vertebra associated with pars interarticularis fracture of C2 which may extend up to the posterior body wall. Neurologic injury is unusual. 

Treatment:

Undisplaced fractures can be treated using semi-rigid arthrosis until united. Reduction with in-line traction followed by a semi-rigid collar in fractures with dislocation more than 3.5mm without kyphotic angulation. In cases of C2/C3 facet dislocation, open reduction and stabilization are required.

Other options:

Option A- Dens fracture is the fracture of the odontoid process of the C2 vertebra.

Option C- Clay shoveller’s fracture is the avulsion of the spinous process of the seventh cervical vertebra.

Below is the radiograph showing Clay shoveller's fracture:

 

Option D- Jefferson's fracture is the burst fracture of the ring of the C1 vertebra/Atlas.

Below is the CT image showing Jefferson's fracture:

questions.text: A newborn developed tachypnea and grunting immediately after birth. On examination, the baby was cyanotic, with a scaphoid abdomen. A chest radiograph was taken, which is shown below. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing herniation of the bowel loops into the chest and absence of bowel loops in the abdomen are suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Bag and mask ventilation is to be avoided in the management of this baby.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect of the diaphragm. Malformation of the diaphragm allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity, hindering proper lung formation and resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia. The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia and in most cases involving the left side. CDH is a life-threatening pathology in infants and a major cause of morbidity and mortality due to two complications: pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension.

Babies with CDH present with respiratory distress characterized by tachypnea, grunting, use of accessory muscles, and cyanosis. They may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter. Auscultation of the chest may reveal bowel sounds with reduced breath sounds.

Diagnosis: A chest radiograph and nasogastric tube passage can confirm the diagnosis of CDH. Prenatal diagnosis can be made using ultrasonography between 16 to 24 weeks of gestation.

Treatment:

The immediate step in the management is the naso- or orogastric tube placement for decompression. The airway is to be secured with endotracheal intubation (option B) and respiratory distress is stabilised. Bag and mask ventilation may increase the abdominal distension and limit the expansion of the hypoplastic lungs. Hence, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided.

Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) (option A) and high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (Option D) have been used as a part of the ventilation strategy to support respiratory failure. The main goal is to maintain oxygenation to the lungs and carbon dioxide washout without causing volutrauma.

Surgical repair of the defect is to be considered at least 48 hours after stabilization and resolution of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text:
A young man complains of occasional cough and blood in the sputum, myalgia, and joint pains. He also reports having noticed blood in his urine for the past several days. He has a history of chronic sinusitis, and examination revealed nasal ulcerations. The investigations and the chest radiograph are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Pulmonary tissue biopsy: Vasculitis and necrotizing granulomas
Serology: Positive for ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies)
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). The patient shows the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (chronic sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (occasional hemoptysis and cavity in the radiograph), renal system (blood in the urine), and the presence of ANCA antibodies and necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis.

It is a granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis of the small vessels that mainly affects both the upper and lower respiratory tracts and glomerulonephritis.

  • Upper respiratory tract presents with sinusitis, otitis media, and nasal septal perforation.
  • Lower respiratory tract presents with hemoptysis, dyspnea, and cough.
  • Glomerulonephritis presents with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. Initially, it appears as focal or segmental glomerulonephritis on biopsy. If this is left untreated, it leads to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Apart from these organs, the disease can also affect the eye and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules.

Laboratory investigations will show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and ANCA positivity. Chest radiograph will show multiple bilateral cavitating nodules and pulmonary infiltrates. 

The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy. Pulmonary tissue is preferred for biopsy other tissues are obtained from the skin and upper airways and rarely in the kidneys.

Other options:

Option A: Henoch-Schönlein purpura is seen mainly in children. They present with polyarthralgia, colicky abdominal pain, blood and mucus per rectum, hematuria, etc. A skin biopsy will show leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition by immunofluorescence.

Option B: Microscopic polyangiitis predominantly affects capillaries, venules, and small and medium-sized arteries. In addition to symptoms like fever and body pains, they can have hemoptysis, glomerulonephritis, mononeuritis multiplex, etc. However, upper respiratory tract involvement and pulmonary nodules are rarely seen in this condition, and a biopsy will show vasculitis without any granulomas.

Option D: Takayasu arteritis is the inflammation of the medium to large-sized arteries. It mainly affects the aortic arch and its branches. The most commonly affected artery is the subclavian artery. Patients will present with features of arm claudication, Raynaud's phenomenon, etc. They can also present with syncope, transient ischemic attack, abdominal pain, or chest pain, depending on the arteries involved. A biopsy of the affected artery will show panarteritis with mononuclear cell infiltrates and occasionally giant cells.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old lady underwent copper-T IUCD insertion 2 months after the delivery of her baby. She has now presented with pain abdomen. The tail of the IUCD is not visible. Her pelvic radiograph is shown below. The most appropriate step in the management of this patient is:

IUCD: Intrauterine contraceptive device
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the IUCD outside the uterine cavity, most likely due to perforation. The most appropriate step in the management of this patient is the removal of the IUCD by laparotomy. 

The tail of the IUCD is not visible when the IUCD is misplaced. The reasons for misplaced IUCD include:

  • Enlargement of the uterus due to pregnancy
  • Curling of the threads inside the uterus
  • Perforation of the uterus
  • IUCD buried in the myometrium
  • Spontaneous expulsion

A plain X-ray or pelvic ultrasound is used in the localization of the IUCD when the IUCD threads cannot be visualized. In this patient, the misplaced IUCD is seen laterally displaced in the pelvic cavity. An abnormal location or abnormal shape of IUCD indicates likely perforation of the uterus. 

Perforation can occur either at the time of insertion (immediate traumatic perforation) or due to gradual erosion of the myometrium (secondary perforation). The risk factors for uterine perforation include:

  • Insertion by less experienced clinicians
  • Post-partum insertion (<6 months since delivery)
  • A higher number of previous abortions
  • Lower parity
  • Lactation

Management:

If the location of the IUCD is inside the uterine cavity, it can be removed using Shirodkar's hook (Option A), a curette, or a hysteroscope (option B) and ultrasound guidance.

In perforation of the uterus, a laparotomy is done as copper-T gets adhered to the omentum or gut and will be difficult to be removed using a laparoscope.

Other options:

Option D- Spontaneous expulsion is one of the reasons for misplaced IUCD. It is not a management approach. The factors that are associated with increased risk of spontaneous expulsion of the IUCD are age <20 years and nulliparity. Expulsion tends to occur at the time of menstruation and is associated with cramping, bleeding, and vaginal discharge.

Here the IUCD has caused perforation of the uterus and is lodged outside the uterus, hence, spontaneous expulsion will not be possible. 

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year Contraceptive
First tier  < 2 % IUCD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal - oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the orthopedic unit with a cubitus valgus deformity. He gives a history of fracture at the elbow when he was a kid and showed the below radiograph that was taken at the time of fracture. Which of the following nerves will be at risk of palsy in this patient?
questions.solution:
The ulnar nerve will be at risk of palsy in this patient. 

The image shows lateral condyle fracture of the humerus. Non-union of this fracture results in cubitus valgus deformity. The cubitus valgus deformity leads to the stretching of the ulnar nerve resulting in classic neuropathic symptoms which is termed as tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Paresthesia in the ulnar nerve distribution with atrophy of the intrinsic hand muscles can be seen. It can be treated with ulnar nerve transposition and cubitus valgus correction.

Lateral condyle fractures usually occur between the age group 4-6 years and are due to fall on an outstretched hand that results in avulsion of the lateral condyle of the humerus. 

The elbow will be swollen and deformed with tenderness over the lateral condyle. Diagnosis is by the different views in a radiograph.

Treatment: An undisplaced fracture can be treated with a long-arm cast for 4-6 weeks and monitored closely for any late displacements. A displaced fracture should be treated with open reduction and internal fixation.

The lateral condylar fracture can lead to various complications including physeal arrest, physeal stimulation, osteonecrosis, and non-union with resultant cubitus valgus. Osteonecrosis of the capitellum results in a fish-tail deformity.

Other options: The anterior interosseous nerve, median nerve, and radial nerve injury are found in supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

Related Pearl: Fractures of necessity

Fractures of necessity are those that require surgery for management. These include:

  • Lateral condyle fracture humerus 
  • Displaced fractured of olecranon and patella
  • Fracture neck of femur
  • Galeazzi fracture-dislocation 
  • Monteggia fracture in adults
  • Intra-articular fractures

questions.text: The cystographic evaluation of a woman with recurrent urinary tract infection is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given cystogram shows an elongated and pointed bladder with a thickened trabeculated wall, called a Christmas tree or pine cone bladder. This is seen in patients with severe neurogenic bladder and increased sphincter tone.

Neurogenic bladder is a term applied to a dysfunctional urinary bladder that results from an injury to the central or peripheral nerves that control and regulate urination. It causes detrusor sphincter dyssynergia. Neurogenic bladder typically occurs due to suprasacral lesions (above S2-S4) or apical lesions (in and around S2-S4).

Pine cone bladder is not pathognomonic of a neurogenic bladder. It may also be seen in patients with lesions anywhere along the sacral reflex arc. Occasionally, it is also seen in bladder neck obstruction of a non-neurogenic cause.

Other options:

Option A: Tuberculous cystitis results in fibrosis and stiffening of the entire urinary bladder, leading to an inability to expand and a significant reduction in bladder capacity, as depicted in the image below. The medical term for this feature on micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is a thimble bladder. 

Option C: In bladder carcinoma, lesions are seen on the wall of the bladder and a biopsy is taken to confirm the diagnosis. These lesions cause disruption in the mucosa and the musculature of the bladder. Cystourethroscopy is the mainstay for the diagnosis of bladder carcinoma. It is performed on patients with hematuria. The most common radiological sign is a filling defect seen in intravenous urography (IVU). 

Option D: Schistosomiasis of the bladder is a parasitic infection by Schistosoma hematobium. The radiographic features in the acute phase is nodular bladder wall thickening, and in the chronic phase, it is the contracted fibrotic, thick-walled bladder and curvilinear calcifications due to large numbers of calcified eggs in the bladder wall. On cystoscopy, it can look like nodules, pseudotubercles, ulceration, and sandy patches, and in the end stage, it can cause squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.

The CT-KUB image below shows circumferential calcification of the bladder wall.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old female patient presents with complaints of chronic cough, fatigue, joint pains, and swelling of both cheeks. She also complains of painful rashes on her knees which were diagnosed as erythema nodosum. On examination, the pulse rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 19/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Her chest X-Ray is shown below. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this condition?

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone
questions.solution:
The clinical features, X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, together with the presence of erythema nodosum, suggests the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. Hypercalcemia is seen in patients with sarcoidosis. 

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology that is characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas.

In acute cases, patients may typically present with Lofgren’s syndrome, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum, uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lethargy, and occasional fever. Patients may also present with insidious onset of cough, breathlessness, and radiographic infiltrates.

An image of erythema nodosum is shown below:

 

Investigations:

  • Lymphopenia and deranged liver function tests are usually seen.
  • Hypercalcemia is seen that is due to the increased synthesis of calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D) by the granuloma. In some patients, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.
  • Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa. Bronchial and transbronchial biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. An increased CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio may be seen in bronchoalveolar lavage.
  • Chest X-ray is useful for staging sarcoidosis.
  • HRCT shows reticulonodular opacities and peribronchial thickening that are predominant in the subpleural areas.

Below is an image of the chest X-ray (a) and coronal (a’) high resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scans showing the typical symmetric reticulonodular opacities of sarcoidosis:

 

Note:

  • Hypercalcemia and/or hypercalciuria occurs in about 10% of sarcoidosis patients. It is more common in whites than African Americans and in men.
  • The mechanism of abnormal calcium metabolism is increased production of 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D by the granuloma itself.
  • The 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D causes increased intestinal absorption of calcium, leading to hypercalcemia with a suppressed parathyroid hormone (PTH) level.

 Treatment options:

  • Glucocorticoids remain the main drug of choice in the treatment of sarcoidosis.
  • In those patients who require persistent corticosteroids, the following steroid-sparing alternatives are considered 
    • Hydroxychloroquine 
    • Methotrexate
    • Azathioprine
    • Leflunomide
    • Mycophenolate
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Thalidomide to some extent in a limited number of cases

Other options:

Option B- Although patients with chronic cough should be evaluated for tuberculosis, a tuberculin test is unlikely to be positive in this patient with typical features of sarcoidosis.

Option C- Stratosphere sign is seen on ultrasound in patients with pneumothorax. The below image shows the same.

 

Option D- Elevated ACTH is seen in patients with small cell carcinoma as a paraneoplastic syndrome leading to Cushingoid features.

questions.text: The renal angiographic picture of a patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given renal angiographic image depicts the 'string of beads' sign, characterized by alternating areas of stenoses and small aneurysms in the renal arteries. This appearance is typical of fibromuscular dysplasia, a renovascular cause of secondary hypertension.

Fibromuscular dysplasia is a segmental, non-atheromatous, dysplastic type of angiopathy characterized by focal irregular thickening in medium and large muscular arteries predominantly affecting females. The most common subtype is medial fibroplasia. The most common sites of involvement in decreasing order of frequency are as follows: Renal arteries > carotid arteries > peripheral (limb) arteries - most commonly iliac arteries.

The typical presentation is in the young person, commonly females with new-onset hypertension. 

Medial fibroplasia is typically seen as a 'string of beads' appearance on CT angiography.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient came with complaints of backache. On radiography, the following image is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hemangioma. The radiograph shows the vertebral body depicting vertical striations, giving a corduroy appearance.

Hemangioma is typically a benign tumor of the vertebral body. This tumor is mostly clinically silent and is usually detected incidentally. The vertebral body is the most common location for hemangioma. The atypical location of hemangioma is the posterior elements of the vertebra and is indicative of an aggressive lesion. Symptomatic hemangiomas usually present with pain, neurologic compromise, or fractures.

Radiographs show large lesions with vertical striations and coarse, thick trabeculae, giving a corduroy appearance. On an axial computed tomography (CT) scan, hemangioma shows a classic polka dot appearance. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the standard for diagnosing hemangiomas.

Treatment: Most hemangiomas do not require treatment. Vertebroplasty is useful in aggressive hemangiomas. 

The below CT image shows characteristic polka dot appearance (left) and corduroy appearance (right):

 

Other options:

Option A: Eosinophilic granuloma is a benign lesion of the vertebral body with a classic radiographic finding of vertebra plana, as shown below.

 

Option C: Paget disease is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by an increase in bone turnover at localized sites that is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone. A radiograph of the vertebra gives a diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity that is referred to as the ivory vertebra appearance, as shown below.

 

Option D: Osteoporosis is a metabolic bone disorder that is characterized by a low bone mass and defects in bone structure, thus rendering the bone unusually fragile and at greater risk of fracture compared to a person of the same age, sex, and race. On a vertebral radiograph, there is a biconcave appearance of the vertebra known as the codfish vertebra, as shown below.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with cough and hemoptysis. There is a history of loss of weight and appetite. On further evaluation, the patient is diagnosed with bronchogenic carcinoma. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following sign is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A Golden S sign is seen in this patient.

Golden S sign is a radiographical appearance seen in the right upper lobe collapse in bronchogenic carcinoma. Due to the central tumor mass associated with lobar collapse, the fissure will not be able to move as usual and it thus creates a bulge giving an S shape pattern on the radiograph. This S shape appearance is known as the Golden S sign. However, this sign is not specific to bronchogenic carcinoma and can occur in other etiologies involving lymphadenopathy or primary mediastinal tumors.

Below is the radiograph showing the Golden S sign. (The orange circle denotes the central tumor, and the green arrow represents the direction of expansion while inspiration)

Other options:

Option A- Luftsichel sign is seen in upper lobe collapse. It is the overinflation of the superior segment of the ipsilateral lower lobe that occupies between the mediastinum and the medial aspect of the upper lobe which results in paramediastinal translucency. This is usually seen more commonly on the left side.

Below is the radiograph of the Luftsichel sign.

Option B- Westermark sign is seen in chest radiographs of patients with pulmonary embolism, indicating focal oligemia.

Option C- Hampton's hump is a wedge-shaped consolidation in the peripheral area of the lungs that may indicate infarction in pulmonary embolism.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A plain radiograph of a patient who was involved in a road traffic accident is as given below. During clinical examination his limb would be found to be:
questions.solution:
The plain radiograph of this patient shows anterior dislocation of the hip. On physical examination, the affected limb will be abducted and externally rotated. 

Other findings in anterior dislocation of the hip joint include a slightly flexed limb and a prominent anterior bulge in the pubic or groin region. According to the position assumed by the femoral head, anterior dislocation of the hip can further be classified as -

  • Type I - If the femoral head is felt anteriorly it is called as the superior/pubic type
  • Type II - If the femoral head is felt in the groin it is called as the inferior/obturator type

On an X-ray, the displaced femoral head will appear larger than the normal side. A lateral view X-ray will be confirmatory. 

The most common nerve injured in an anterior hip dislocation is the femoral nerve.

Treatment of anterior dislocation includes a closed reduction under sedation or general anesthesia. If closed reduction fails, an open procedure may be planned. 

The image below shows, a patient with an externally rotated, abducted, and slightly flexed left leg due to anterior dislocation of the hip:

 

Posterior dislocation of the hip is more common than anterior dislocation. It is caused due to a high energy impact to the knee, forcing the femoral head posteriorly.

On examination, the limb is adducted and internally rotated in a posterior dislocation of the hip. It also tends to be shortened and slightly flexed. On an X-ray, the displaced femoral head is higher and appears smaller than the normal side.

The most common nerve injured is the sciatic nerve as it lies behind the posterior wall of the acetabulum.

Treatment of posterior dislocation includes a closed reduction under sedation or general anesthesia. 

X-ray showing posterior dislocation of the hip:

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with complaints of dysphagia, fever, stridor, drooling, and muffled voice. The following image is seen on a lateral x-ray of the neck. What is the finding seen in the given radiograph?
questions.solution:
Thumb sign is seen on the given lateral view radiograph.

The above clinical features of a toxic looking child with high-grade fever, tachypnea, stridor, dysphagia with salivary drooling are suggestive of acute epiglottitis. Thumb sign on lateral X-ray of neck is pathognomonic for acute epiglottitis. 

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive confined to supraglottic structures i.e., epiglottis, aryepiglottic fold and arytenoids. It usually affects children of age 2-7 years. It has a potentially fulminating course of fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and rapidly progressing respiratory obstruction.

Management:

Indirect laryngoscopy shows edema and congestion of supraglottic structures. A lateral X-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis giving an appearance called the thumb sign.

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency due to sudden and unpredictable airway obstruction. The treatment includes the following:

  • Admission to ICU
  • Airway management - endotracheal intubation, tracheostomy for respiratory obstruction
  • Antibiotics - Ampicillin or third-generation cephalosporin is indicated in the treatment of acute epiglottitis along with airway management.
  • Dexamethasone may be given to reduce pharyngeal edema

Other options:

Option A: Steeple sign is seen in laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

Option C- Below image shows adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option D- Omega shaped epiglottis is seen in laryngomalacia. This finding is seen in direct laryngoscopy.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a left-sided breast lump which she noticed only for the past 6 months but ignored. She has no other complaints. On palpation, the lump is mobile and firm. A mammogram revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is fibroadenoma. The image shows popcorn calcifications in the breast mammogram which are characteristic of fibroadenoma of the breast.

Fibroadenomas are benign solid tumors composed of stromal and epithelial elements.

Fibroadenomas present as firm masses that are easily movable and may increase in size over several months and wax and wane with the menstrual cycle. They slide easily under the examining fingers and maybe lobulated or smooth. On excision, fibroadenomas are well-encapsulated masses.

On mammography, fibroadenomas show popcorn calcification. However, mammography cannot discriminate between cysts and fibroadenomas. Ultrasonography can be performed to distinguish between fibroadenoma and cysts.

Management includes reassurance of the patient. However, if the patient is bothered by the mass or if the mass continues to grow, it is removed with an open excisional biopsy or via a percutaneous approach.

Giant fibroadenoma is a type of fibroadenoma that attains an unusually large size (typically >5 cm). The term juvenile fibroadenoma refers to a large fibroadenoma that occasionally occurs in adolescents and young adults and histologically is more cellular than the usual fibroadenoma.

Other types of calcifications on a mammogram:

A broken-needle type of calcification is seen in duct ectasia (option A)

 

Egg-shell calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis (option C)

 

Tea-cup calcification is seen in fibrocystic disease (Option D)

questions.text: A middle-aged patient with a duodenal diverticulum who underwent surgery the previous day and has been nil per os since the surgery complains of abdominal pain. The surgeon was wearing a bracelet with a coin attached during the surgery despite being warned by the nurse. The abdominal radiograph is shown below. Under which doctrine will the surgeon be held responsible?
questions.solution:
The image shows a coin in the abdomen that was absent before the surgery. As the patient was nil per os after the surgery, this implies that the coin from the bracelet had fallen inside the abdomen during the surgery and the surgeon completed the surgery without removing it. The surgeon will be held responsible under res ipsa loquitur.

Res ipsa loquitur means "the thing or fact speaks for itself." It implies that the negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence. The patient has to only state the negligent act. This doctrine applies to both civil and criminal negligence. All of the following conditions should be fulfilled for this doctrine:

  • In the absence of negligence, there would not have been any injury usually.
  • The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.
  • The patient was not a part of contributory negligence.

Other options:

Option A - Res indicata is a defense for the doctor against negligence. This specifies that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed beyond two years would be dismissed as it would be beyond the period of limitation.

Option C - Contributory negligence is the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant along with the doctor's negligence contributing to the injury without which the injury would not have occurred. It acts as a partial defense against negligence for the doctor. In the given scenario, the patient was nil per os, indicating that there was no provision for foreign body consumption and suggesting there is no contributory negligence by the patient.

Option D - Medical maloccurrence occurs when the patient does not respond properly or faces adverse effects in spite of good attention and care by the doctor.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: An elderly patient presented with easy fatiguability and backache. He has had recurrent infections in the past 3 months. Reports showed hypercalcemia. His skull x-ray is  below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple myeloma is the most likely diagnosis for this patient. The given radiograph represents the multiple well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions of various sizes scattered throughout the skull, giving the raindrop skull appearance, which is seen in multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is the malignant production of plasma cells that results in bone pain or fractures, renal failure, increased susceptibility to infections, anemia, hypercalcemia, and manifestations of hyperviscosity. The incidence of multiple myeloma increases with age, and it is more commonly seen in males than in females.

Bone pain is the most common symptom and is due to the proliferation of tumor cells, stimulation of osteoclasts that destroy the bone, and inhibition of osteoblast cells that form new bone resulting in osteolytic lesions. Recurrent infections in multiple myeloma are due to hypogammaglobulinemia. Hypercalcemia results from the chronic mobilization of calcium from bones.

Revised International Myeloma Working Group criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) Biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

Plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder: (specifically CRAB features)
    • HyperCalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance of <40 mL/min or serum creatinine level of >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level >20 g/L (2 mg/dL) below the lowest limit of normal or hemoglobin level of <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron-emission tomography (PET)/CT
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%
    • Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater
    • >1 focal lesion on MRI that is at least 5 mm or greater in size

Option A - Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by multiple tiny, well-defined lucencies in the skull due to the resorption of trabecular bone, resulting in the salt and pepper appearance or pepper pot skull. The clinical features are mainly due to hypercalcemia and typically include anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, depression, fatigue, and muscle weakness. Renal stones/nephrocalcinosis can occur due to hypercalciuria. Joint symptoms occur due to chondrocalcinosis.

Other radiological findings in hyperparathyroidism:

  • Sub-periosteal resorption of middle phalanges - Classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism
  • Loss of lamina dura 
  • An atypical cyst-like lytic lesion, otherwise known as brown tumor 

Option C - Paget's disease is characterized by excessive bone remodeling. Most cases are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally on a radiograph or a raised alkaline phosphatase level. The symptoms include pain and deformities of the bones and cranial nerve palsy due to compression. The characteristic skull radiographic finding is the presence of mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull, which is referred to as the cotton wool appearance. 

Other radiographic findings in Paget's disease:

  • Picture frame vertebra
  • Squaring of vertebra on lateral radiographs
  • Blade of grass appearance in long bones

Option D- Eosinophilic granuloma is a mild form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis and is characterized by abnormal proliferation of Langerhans cells, with an abundance of eosinophils, neutrophils, and lymphocytes. It results in medullary bone resorption. It usually presents with pain and swelling in the affected area. Otitis media and mastoiditis occur if the calvarium is involved. Compression fractures and neurological symptoms occur in spinal involvement. The characteristic skull finding is the geographic skull and solitary or multiple lytic lesions, with a beveled-edge appearance.

Other radiographic findings in eosinophilic granuloma:

  • Vertebra plana
  • Floating tooth in the mandible

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: A 16-month-child is brought with a history of abdominal distension and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and there appears to be hepatosplenomegaly. The radiograph of the child is given below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is Hurler's syndrome.

As the child presents with mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea and given x-ray shows a J-shaped sella turcica and a thickened calvaria, the most likely diagnosis is Hurler's Syndrome.

Hurler's syndrome is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparan sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs (seen below)
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

 

Other options:

Option A- Tay-Sachs disease is a hereditary neurodegenerative disorder due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase-A resulting in the excess storage of GM2 ganglioside within the lysosomes of cells. The clinical features include developmental delay, intellectual impairment, seizures, and breathing difficulty.

The CT image shows macrocephaly and reduced attenuation of the cerebral white matter. MRI can delineate deep white matter demyelination, and indicate calcification in thalami on T2 weighted sequences.

Option C- Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder characterized by autosomal recessive inheritance due to the deficiency of the glucocerebrosidase enzyme. This results in the accumulation of a glycolipid (glucocerebroside) within the lysosomes of macrophages.

The clinical features include bone pain, pathological fractures, bone crises hepatosplenomegaly, and hematological disturbances.

The radiological features of the skeletal involvement include osteopenia, osteonecrosis, fractures (pathological), Erlenmeyer flask deformity, and H-shaped vertebra.

Option D- Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 2 resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

The clinical features include abnormal facies characterized by the prominent forehead, flattened nasal bridge, coarse facies, gingival hyperplasia, macroglossia, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, macrocephaly, intellectual disability, hepatosplenomegaly.

These patients lack clouding of the cornea.

The radiological features include thickened calvaria, enlargement of the skull, broad clavicle and ribs, thoracolumbar kyphosis, hip dysplasia, and genu valgum deformity.

questions.text: An elderly male patient is brought to the casualty with complaints of vomiting and severe abdominal pain. The abdomen appears grossly distended, is tender to touch, and percussion reveals hyper-resonance. His X-ray abdomen is shown in the image below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Laparotomy followed by sigmoid resection alone
Insertion of a rectal tube through a flexible sigmoidoscope

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray radiograph showing characteristic coffee bean appearance are highly suggestive of sigmoid volvulus. Non-operative decompression followed by insertion of a rectal tube through a rigid proctoscope or a flexible sigmoidoscope is the next best step in the management of this patient.

Sigmoid volvulus is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. Symptoms include constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. Onset may be acute or chronic. It occurs more commonly in patients with a history of mental illness and chronic constipation.

X-ray abdomen shows a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include the coffee bean sign and the absence of rectal gas. CT may reveal large gas-filled loop without haustral markings, forming a closed-loop obstruction.

Non-operative decompression is successful in treating 90% of the patients. The rectal tube should be left in place for 1-2 days to allow complete decompression and to prevent immediate recurrence of the volvulus. This should be followed by bowel cleansing with cathartics and a complete colonoscopic examination. In patients with signs of colonic necrosis or in whom endoscopic detorsion has failed, sigmoid colectomy with the closure of the rectum and end colostomy (Hartmann procedure) maybe required. Even if detorsion of the sigmoid is successful, elective sigmoid resection is indicated to prevent recurrence.
